channel.title: Linux on Omri Bornstein
channel.description: Recent content in Linux on Omri Bornstein

item.title: Command-line Shell Configuration
item.description: This document summarises how I set-up my UNIX-like command-line environment (on Linux and macOS) for easier interaction with command-line interfaces (CLIs).

item.title: SHELL CTF How to Defeat a Dragon
item.description: Prompt # Dragonairre, the dragon with the hexadecimal head has attacked the village to take revenge on his last defeat, we need to get the ultimate weapon.

item.title: UACTF Sanity Check
item.description: Prompt # I didn’t know that strings was a command until way later LMAO.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 25 - 26
item.description: Prompt # Logging in to bandit26 from bandit25 should be fairly easy The shell for user bandit26 is not /bin/bash, but something else.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 24 - 25
item.description: Prompt # A daemon is listening on port 30002 and will give you the password for bandit25 if given the password for bandit24 and a secret numeric 4-digit PIN code.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 23 - 24
item.description: Prompt # A program is running automatically at regular intervals from cron, the time-based job scheduler.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 22 - 23
item.description: Prompt # A program is running automatically at regular intervals from cron, the time-based job scheduler.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 21 - 22
item.description: Prompt # A program is running automatically at regular intervals from cron, the time-based job scheduler.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 20 - 21
item.description: Prompt # There is a setuid binary in the home directory that does the following:

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 19 - 20
item.description: Prompt # To gain access to the next level, you should use the setuid binary in the home directory.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 18 - 19
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in a file readme in the home directory.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 17 - 18
item.description: Prompt # There are 2 files in the home directory: passwords.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 16 - 17
item.description: Prompt # The credentials for the next level can be retrieved by submitting the password of the current level to a port on localhost in the range 31000 to 32000.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 15 - 16
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level can be retrieved by submitting the password of the current level to port 30001 on localhost using SSL encryption.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 14 - 15
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level can be retrieved by submitting the password of the current level to port 30000 on localhost.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 13 - 14
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in /etc/bandit_pass/bandit14 and can only be read by user bandit14.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 12 - 13
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in the file data.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 11 - 12
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in the file data.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 10 - 11
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in the file data.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 9 - 10
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in the file data.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 8 - 9
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in the file data.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 7 - 8
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in the file data.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 6 - 7
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored somewhere on the server and has all of the following properties:

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 5 - 6
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in a file somewhere under the inhere directory and has all of the following properties:

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 4 - 5
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in the only human-readable file in the inhere directory.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 3 - 4
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in a hidden file in the inhere directory.

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 2 - 3
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in a file called spaces in this filename located in the home directory

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 1 - 2
item.description: Prompt # The password for the next level is stored in a file called - located in the home directory

item.title: OverTheWire Bandit Level 0 - 1
item.description: This is my attempt at OverTheWire’s Bandit challenges.

item.title: raker
item.description: A social media scraper that is interfaced via a server-side rendered HTML user interface (or a CLI), and is managed by a REST API and a NoSQL database.

item.title: stalk
item.description: A cross-platform file-watcher that can run a command after each file-system operation on a given files or simply wait once until a file is changed.

item.title: cocainate
item.description: A cross-platform re-implementation of the macOS utility caffeinate that keeps the screen turned on either until stopped, for a set duration of time or while another process still runs.

item.title: FIT2082 computer science research project
item.description: As part of the FIT2082 unit, I contributed to an existing codebase, based on prior research by (Gange, Harabor and Stuckey, 2021) about Lazy CBS, their Multi-Agent Path Finding (MAPF) algorithm.

item.title: sp
item.description: My first attempt at building a Minecraft server plugin.

item.title: scr-web
item.description: My previous attempt at building a full-stack social media scraper, which is built with Angular on the front-end, and Nest on the back-end.

item.title: scr-cli
item.description: My previous attempt at building a CLI social media scraper, which is built with OCLIF.
